There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of occlusal splint or nocturnal bite plate in the treatment of bruxism.

The evidence from the included trials is insufficient to determine whether interferon is effective in treating chronic hepatitis D. The evidence from the included trials is insufficient to determine whether interferon is effective in treating chronic hepatitis D.

Atrial natriuretic peptide treatment is effective in reducing the incidence of postoperative arrhythmias and the frequency of hemodialysis. However, the incidence of acute renal failure was not significantly reduced.
Progestogen-only and progestogen-only combined oral contraceptives appear to have similar effects on bone mineral density.
There is insufficient evidence to determine whether lucinactant is superior to poractant alfa in the prevention of preterm birth or neonatal mortality.
The evidence from the two included trials was insufficient to determine whether natalizumab is beneficial or harmful for patients with Crohn's disease.
The evidence from the included trials was insufficient to determine whether formoterol is superior to placebo in the treatment of COPD.
There is evidence that ultrasound during embryo transfer improves clinical pregnancy rates in IVF cycles. The evidence is not strong enough to recommend the use of ultrasound during embryo transfer.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of nutritional support for burns.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of oxygen supplementation during caesarean section.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of EMG -based antenatal training for women in labour.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any specific type of breast-pumping method. Further research is needed to determine which types of breast-pumping methods are most effective and to determine which types of breast-pumping methods are most comfortable to use.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of external fixator for people with distal radius fractures.

Propofol is an acceptable alternative to midazolam and meperidine for colonoscopy.

Alvimopan and methylnaltrexone significantly reduced the time to first bowel movement and improved bowel motility. Naloxone and methylnaltrexone significantly increased the time to first bowel movement. Morphine significantly increased the time to first bowel movement.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of glyceryl trinitrate for the treatment of supraspinatus tendon pain.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of group voice therapy for people with dysphonia.
The evidence from the trials included in this review does not support the use of NSAIDs in the treatment of AD.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of surgery for chronic closed lock of the TMJ.
Patients with head and neck cancer should be offered chemotherapy in addition to radiotherapy.

Combination chemotherapy is an effective treatment for women with advanced or recurrent cervical cancer. However, the evidence is not strong enough to recommend a specific combination of chemotherapy and radiotherapy.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the routine use of influenza vaccines in children with cancer.
Two doses of influenza vaccine are more effective than one dose in inducing immunogenic responses in patients with cancer.
Duloxetine is an effective treatment for MDD. Duloxetine is associated with a higher rate of discontinuation due to TEAEs than paroxetine.

N-acetylcysteine is effective in reducing mortality and increasing survival in patients with fulminant hepatic failure. However, it does not reduce mortality or increase survival in patients with acute renal failure.
Zinc supplementation in children does not reduce mortality or morbidity.

The risk of death and bleeding was significantly higher in the laparoscopic group. Lymph node dissection was associated with a significantly longer operating time and a significantly longer hospital stay.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of anti-tetanus s in preventing or treating tetanus.

TEA is effective in reducing mortality and improving postoperative hemodynamic parameters. However, it does not reduce length of stay or time to tracheal extubation.

Psychological therapy is an effective treatment for PTSD in children and young people. The evidence is not strong enough to recommend any specific type of psychological therapy for children and young people with PTSD.

The evidence from randomised controlled trials is insufficient to determine whether breastfeeding reduces the risk of HIV transmission. Further research is needed to determine whether breastfeeding reduces the risk of HIV transmission.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of personal health education to improve primary care.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of IFN-alpha-2A in the treatment of ulcerative colitis.
Budesonide/formoterol is an effective treatment for COPD. The risk of pneumonia was significantly reduced. Budesonide/formoterol is well tolerated.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of aerobic exercise for patients with RA.

Oral acyclovir is an effective treatment for herpes zoster. Acyclovir is associated with a reduction in the incidence of painful postherpetic neuralgia, a reduction in the duration of pain, a reduction in the number of lesions and a reduction in the time to healing. However, the evidence is not strong enough to recommend the use of acyclovir for herpes zoster.
There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of tranexamic acid in patients with scoliosis undergoing posterior spinal fusion surgery.

The evidence from this review suggests that routine weaning of mechanical ventilation in adults is safe and may reduce the length of hospital stay and the rate of reintubation. However, the evidence is based on a small number of studies with small sample sizes and is not generalisable.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of tight control of blood pressure in women with mild or severe pre-eclampsia or gestational hypertension.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of antibiotics for children with covert bacteriuria.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of disulfiram for the treatment of cocaine dependence.
Budesonide/formoterol is an effective treatment for COPD. The adverse events associated with the treatment are similar to those associated with placebo.

Aliskiren is an effective treatment for hypertension. Aliskiren is effective in reducing systolic and diastolic blood pressure. Aliskiren is also effective in reducing fasting BP. Aliskiren is well tolerated.
The seizure frequency was significantly reduced with the use of the slow-release formulation of CBZ. The adverse effects were less frequent with the slow-release formulation.

Alprazolam and citalopram are effective in treating depression in patients with MI. IPT is effective in treating depression. Citalopram and sertraline are not effective.

There is evidence that spinal manipulation is an effective treatment for chronic low-back pain. Calcitriol is effective in reducing intact PTH in patients with CKD. However, the evidence is not strong enough to support its use in patients with CKD.

There is evidence that rTMS is an effective treatment for motor function problems following stroke. There is no evidence that rTMS is an effective treatment for cognitive impairment. 5-ASA is an effective treatment for Crohn's disease. Pentasa is not superior to 5-ASA in terms of clinical outcome. 6-ASA is superior to placebo in terms of clinical outcome. 6-ASA is superior to Pentasa in terms of tolerability.

Luteal progesterone supplementation in women undergoing ART is effective in achieving a live birth rate of at least 50% and in women undergoing ART, with a live birth rate of at least 60%.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of telephone notification for HIV testing in young people.

The review provides some evidence that family -directed interventions can prevent the uptake of alcohol and drug use by young people. However, the evidence is based on a small number of studies with small sample sizes and is not robust. Further research is needed to determine whether family-directed interventions are effective and if so, what types of interventions are most effective.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of amniotic membrane transplantation in people with acute ocular burns.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the effectiveness of educational interventions for preventing wrong-site tooth extraction.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of zinc supplementation in people with sickle cell anaemia.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of hysteroscopic polypectomy for women with uterine fibroids.
The MTB/RIF assay is a useful and inexpensive way to detect tuberculosis. It is a simple method that can be used by routine healthcare workers.
There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of multivitamin supplements for pregnant women with HIV infection.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of misoprostol for women with preterm labour.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of aminophylline in the treatment of acute asthma.
The evidence from this review does not support routine use of antibiotics in the treatment of acute exacerbations of COPD.
Milnacipran is an effective treatment for fibromyalgia. Milnacipran is well tolerated by most patients, with nausea and headache being the most common adverse events.

Topiramate is an effective first-line prophylactic drug for the prevention of migraine. Topiramate is associated with a significant reduction in migraine frequency, and a significant reduction in migraine days. Topiramate is associated with a significant increase in adverse events.

Divalproex is an effective prophylactic drug for migraine without aura. The frequency of migraine attacks was reduced in the group treated with divalproex. The duration of migraine attacks was reduced in the group treated with divalproex. The adverse events were mild and transient.
